And what part he has had , and in my heart
I know there is a balance on your side .
Things can n't go on forever in this way .

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: Now the snow falls they 're afraid the wolf will howl .

lg.l: Will you be stronger then a year from now ,
Your Union broken up , your wages less ,
And this defeat behind you dampening all ?
Or do you intend henceforth never to lift
The voice of protest , silent whatever comes ?
God will provide , my friends . Do not give up .
Tell ‘ em about it , partner .

sp.speaker: HARRY EGERTON
sp.p: Their enemies would say it was the gold . And we must show them that they 're wrong .

lg.stage: With a stick he has picked up comes from the mill-yard
lg.l: What do you mean by interfering here ?

div.stage: He discovers Harvey Anderson talking with Harry Egerton and turns , evidently for an explanation , to Haskell
Jubilant , Harvey Anderson turns and , catching up one of the mill-boys , lifts him over his head and slides him down his back , holding him by the feet . Jergens advances toward him

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: I would n't try it , pard , if I were you .

lg.l: You 'll rue this day !
We 'll fix you !
Close these gates !
Clear these streets , Captain !

sp.speaker: HARRY EGERTON
sp.p: Stand where you are , my friends .

sp.speaker: JERGENS
sp.p: Captain , I order you to clear these streets .

sp.speaker: HARRY EGERTON
sp.p: Be careful , Captain Haskell , what you do . This is a public place .

lg.l: Who 's in command here , I should like to know ?

sp.speaker: JERGENS
sp.p: Your father will attend to you , young man .

div.stage: Beside himself with rage , disappears down the street , left

lg.l: Now then go quietly to your homes , my friends ,
And I to-night will see what I can do .

div.stage: Takes his hand

lg.l: Comrades ,
I never thought we 'd live to see this day .

div.stage: The men crowd about them

sp.speaker: HARRY EGERTON
sp.p: Some of you men are hungry .

sp.speaker: THE MEN
sp.p: We 're all right ! We 're all right , Mr. Egerton !

sp.speaker: HARRY EGERTON
sp.p: But never mind . We will begin a new age in this land .

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: Up with your hats , pards ! God 's on the mountains !

div.stage: Tosses his hat into the air . The workmen , in an almost religious ecstasy , go out left , crowding around Harry Egerton and Harvey Anderson . Dicey , King and Masters remain behind , whispering together , then follow the crowd . The militiamen , most of them silent with amazement at the scene they have witnessed , gradually disappear into the mill-yard

sp.speaker: FIRST MILITIAMAN
sp.p: I 'm for young Egerton if it comes to that .

sp.speaker: SECOND MILITIAMAN
sp.p: Most of us boys are sons of workingmen .

lg.l: Buck 's about right , too , kids .
We came here to see the square thing done ,
Not to be half-sole to the old man 's boot .

div.stage: They go into the mill-yard , talking earnestly
The First Sentry joins him and they whisper together

lg.stage: Starts with the other for the gate
lg.l: I 've nothing against Buck .

div.stage: They enter the mill-yard

div.head: ACT III

sp.speaker: THE MANSION
sp.p: Scene : The great reception hall in the Egerton mansion . One sees at a glance that this is the original of the shadow hall shown in the Dream-Vision in the First Act . The carved mountain lion crouches upon the newel-post , and upon the walls the figures of men at work among the pines are identical with those of the Vision . But here , seen under a natural light , the grotesque grandeur of it all stands out in clear relief . Forward , left and right , just where the great arch separating the main hall comes down , groups of little pines in tubs lend a freshness to the scene . A brilliant company is gathered . Everywhere , from gestures and lifted eyes , it is evident that the mansion , especially the strange scene upon the walls , is the chief topic of talk among the guests . Centre right , about the piano , a number of young people are watching a couple that is out upon the floor , apparently practising a new step . Near the pines , forward left , General Chadbourne turns from the butler , with whom he has been speaking , to shake hands with some ladies . Later , Ralph Ardsley appears just inside the door , forward right , and holds up a glass of wine . Two or three men notice him and nudge their companions , and one after another saunter past Ardsley into the side room . Time : The same afternoon about five o'clock .

sp.speaker: RALPH ARDSLEY
sp.p: Get me the eye of Chadbourne .

div.stage: Out on the floor the couple that is waltzing jostles an elderly lady

sp.speaker: LADY IN BLACK
sp.p: Why can n't they wait until ——

sp.speaker: ELDERLY LADY
sp.p: Now run away . You 've got all night for this tomfoolery .

div.stage: The young people gradually drift out into the conservatory

lg.l: For it 's something that concerns the strike .
And I 'll be right out ——
I 'll be right in here .

div.stage: Joins the Second Man , and the two , with Ardsley , disappear into the side room

sp.speaker: YOUNG MATRON
sp.p: Why do you men keep going out that way ?

lg.l: The Governor wants to see us .

div.stage: They go into the room , forward right

lg.stage: Entering forward left with Pale Lady
lg.l: Indeed it would ;
To just have all the money that you want .

sp.speaker: PALE LADY
sp.p: And her new necklace , did you notice it ?

div.stage: They pass rear and mingle with the throng

lg.stage: Appearing forward right with a glass of wine
lg.l: You ladies , I presume , are temperance workers .

div.stage: ‘ The punch ! The punch ! ’ is whispered about , and the people begin to pass out centre and forward right

sp.speaker: FAT LADY
sp.p: I mean to just taste everything there is .

div.stage: Goes out

sp.speaker: LADY IN BLACK
sp.p: Is n't it just too grand for anything !

lg.l: At night , though , I should think ‘ twould scare a body
With all those horrid things upon the walls .

div.stage: They go out . A moment later Mrs. Egerton comes in and looks about as though she were seeking some one

lg.stage: To her daughter , who passes toward the conservatory
lg.l: Please do n't keep showing it , Gladys .

div.stage: She enters the conservatory

sp.speaker: MRS. EGERTON
sp.p: Beckons to some one in the room forward left . The Butler appearsHas no word come ?

lg.l: Jack says that Mr. George inquired
And they 've seen nothing of him .

div.stage: He goes back into the room , forward left . Mrs. Egerton lingers a while , then returns to the room , forward right . Here , a moment later Ralph Ardsley appears

lg.stage: Calls to a group of four men back near the stairs
lg.l: Laggards ! laggards !

div.stage: Bishop Hardbrooke and a fellow-townsman , each with a man who is evidently a stranger , come slowly forward

lg.l: Is n't there aspiration in all this ,
A reaching out toward God , and a love , too ,
Of all that God hath made ?

sp.speaker: RALPH ARDSLEY
sp.p: The walls will be here when the wine is gone .

sp.speaker: FELLOW-TOWNSMAN
sp.p: People do n't stop to think of what he 's done .

lg.l: Exactly . When an axe falls on one 's toes ,
The service that it 's been , that 's out of mind .
And yet you throw the bruise , the moment 's pain ,
In one side , and in the other a cleared land
With homes and fields ——

sp.speaker: BISHOP HARDBROOKE
sp.p: And populous towns . The balance will be struck up yonder , brother .

lg.l: Show me one man that 's in the public eye
Because he stands for something , towers above them ,
That has n't had them yelping at his heels .

sp.speaker: BISHOP HARDBROOKE
sp.p: You know the Editor of the Courier ?

div.stage: The Strangers shake hands with Ardsley
Walks back in the hall

sp.speaker: SECOND STRANGER
sp.p: We were together in the Legislature .

lg.stage: Stopping near the door , forward right , as if for a final word
lg.l: Speaking of Egerton , some years ago
I saw that statue in the New York harbor ,
The sea mists blown about it , now the head
And now an outflash of tremendous bronze
About the waist . ‘ Is that the thing , ’ said I ,
‘ They talk so much about ? ’ Next day ‘ twas clear .

div.stage: They go out

lg.l: I 've got to find a man .
lg.stage: Ardsley calls toward the room , forward left
lg.l: What 's the news from the mill , Charles ?
I have n't heard , sir .
You reckon they 'll go back , sir ?
Sure . Where 's Gladys ?
lg.stage: The Butler walks back toward the conservatory
lg.l: Just tell her I asked about her .

div.stage: He goes into the room , forward right . The Butler returns to the opposite room . All the people have now withdrawn with the exception of Mrs. Orr , who has come in , centre right , and who lingers about as though she were listening to the upper part of the walls . Later , Mrs. Egerton re-enters , forward right , and glances back into the room from which she has come , to satisfy herself that her guests are occupied . Seeing her , Mrs. Orr comes forward , shaking her head

lg.l: I never have been sure myself . Sometimes
I 've thought I heard it .
I can understand
How one could easily imagine it .
If you could be here when the house is still ,
Alone ——
In certain moods , perhaps I should .
For certainly the trees seem most alive .
I never would have thought it possible
To make a forest live and life go on
In wood as it does here . ‘ Tis wonderful .

div.stage: Mrs. Egerton glances across into the room , forward right , from which comes a sound of merriment

lg.l: The very squirrels upon the limbs — see there ,
The young one with the pine cone in its mouth .
And the faint far-awayness of the wood .
Sylvia ——
Just now as the couple passed
Practising , I overheard the girl ,
‘ It almost seems the real pines are here
Dropping their needles on us while we dance .
As Lillian says , you feel them in your hair . ’
Now , to my way of thinking , it would be
Far easier to hear the pine trees sigh
Than feel the needles .
You said a sighing .
lg.stage: Mrs. Egerton says something to her
lg.l: Why , Mary Egerton !
How horrible !

sp.speaker: MRS. ORR
sp.p: You do not mean it ! And the house just built ! You foolish dear .

lg.l: How horrible !
Harry has always been a strange , strange boy ;
So different from the rest . What is it you hear ?
Why , nothing , nothing at all . My dear , this is
Really ridiculous . If it were old
And there were cobwebs here and musty walls
And rumors had come down of some old crime
But with the timber , every stick of it
Fresh from the forest , you might almost say
Picked from your very garden , a pure bloom ,
Fashioned and shaped by your own husband 's hand :
How any one could fancy such a thing
Is past my comprehension .

div.stage: A medley of voices is heard , forward right

sp.speaker: A VOICE
sp.p: Cover his eyes , some of you .

div.stage: She starts back for the door , centre right

sp.speaker: MRS. ORR
sp.p: But we can n't talk in there .

div.stage: They go out centre right . Amid laughter and a confusion of voices Ralph Ardsley and a fellow-townsman enter forward right leading Governor Braddock , whose eyes are blindfolded . Following these come Donald Egerton , General Chadbourne , Bishop Hardbrooke , members of the Governor 's staff in uniform , and other guests

sp.speaker: GOVERNOR BRADDOCK
sp.p: You 'll pay for this , gentlemen , you 'll pay for this .

div.stage: Egerton points back toward the centre of the hall . Himself and the group about him remain more in the foreground
They remove the handkerchief from the Governor 's eyes

sp.speaker: RALPH ARDSLEY
sp.p: You see you wake in Paradise .

div.stage: Laughter

sp.speaker: FIRST STAFF MEMBER
sp.p: You mean to tell us that you planned all this ?

lg.l: No , I conceived it , Weston ; it 's alive
As I hope to show you . But more of that anon .
Does it meet your expectations ?
Splendid ! Splendid !

sp.speaker: FELLOW-TOWNSMAN
sp.p: And in the second story he 's got his mill .

lg.l: You do n't have strikes up there ?
Well , Egerton ,
This is the grandest thing I ever saw .
I made my mind up , Braddock , years ago
That when I 'd sawed my fortune out of lumber
I 'd build a mansion where a man could see
Just how I 'd done it , starting with the raw ,
The standing timber , every phase of it ;
A sort of record of these busy times :
For they wo n't last forever , these great days .

sp.speaker: GENERAL CHADBOURNE
sp.p: We never see the giants till they 're gone .

sp.speaker: BISHOP HARDBROOKE
sp.p: The day will come when we 'll appreciate them .

sp.speaker: RALPH ARDSLEY
sp.p: Three cheers for one of them .

sp.speaker: EGERTON
sp.p: Goes back a little , the group following him , and points right rearBack there you see the swamper clearing brush , Man 's first assault upon primeval forests . And then the feller with his broader stroke Hewing a way for apple trees and cities , And incidentally moving on himself . And here you see my teams . And , by the way , They talk of how the horse has followed man In his march across the ages , but the tree That sheltered the lost saurian , think of that !

lg.l: You must have been a tree in some past life ;
You seem to love them so and understand them .
There 's nothing in this world so beautiful
As a pine forest , gentlemen , just at dawn ;
The infant breathing of a million needles .
It 's like our organ , Bishop , those soft tones .

div.stage: Comes forward

sp.speaker: BISHOP HARDBROOKE
sp.p: He ought to have lived in old cathedral days .

lg.l: And here the rising rollways ; then the drive ,
The river man .

div.stage: Points across left

lg.l: Come out to get a view ,
A broader view .

sp.speaker: THIRD STAFF MEMBER
sp.p: You had men pose for this ?

sp.speaker: EGERTON
sp.p: These ‘ broader views ’ do n't interest me much .

sp.speaker: GOVERNOR BRADDOCK
sp.p: And you think this idea 's capable of extension ?

sp.speaker: GENERAL CHADBOURNE
sp.p: Returning from a word with the Butler , to Ardsley who comes to meet himI do n't see what 's the matter .

lg.l: You were the first Captain of Industry
In all America to build a house .
That has a meaning in it .
That 's what I said ;
That has the least relation to the land .

sp.speaker: RALPH ARDSLEY
sp.p: This snow you 'll see will bring them to their senses .

sp.speaker: GOVERNOR BRADDOCK
sp.p: Suppose you 'd made your fortune out of copper ?

sp.speaker: FIRST STAFF MEMBER
sp.p: Yes , we all build our houses out of timber .

sp.speaker: RALPH ARDSLEY
sp.p: How would you spiritualize the oil business ?

sp.speaker: EGERTON
sp.p: Ardsley here wants to quote me in his paper .

sp.speaker: GENERAL CHADBOURNE
sp.p: The Lumber King upon the late decision .

lg.l: It 's Art , not rebates , that I 'm speaking of .
Could n't I show my derricks on the walls ?
And back there red-skins striking fire from flint ?
Then our forefathers with their tallow-dips
Watching the easy drills slip up and down ?
The tanks here — Ah , you laugh , you dilettanti .
I 'll tell you gentlemen what the trouble is :
You 're frightened by our natural resources ,
And you despise the life of your own land ,
The crude , tremendous life we 're living here .
The force is too much for you . You want polish .
O I can prove it to you .

sp.speaker: EGERTON
sp.p: Yes , Braddock , there 's that Capitol Commission . I 'd be ashamed .

lg.l: And we
Breathing the electric air of this great West ,
As rich in life as timber , herds and hops ,
Wheat fields and mines , and all these things to be
Raised and translated by the brains of men .
Think of a State dotted with lumber camps
And buzzing day and night with saws and saws ,
And as far as the North Pole from old world customs ,
Wearing a capitol with Grecian columns
With an old Roman Justice on her comb !
You 'd scorn to come here in a gaberdine
Made by some dago in the days of Pompey .
And yet you dress the State up in these things .
No independence .
I 'd rather cut the timber of this land
And coin its spirit in a thing like this
Than be a Roman Caesar .

sp.speaker: RALPH ARDSLEY
sp.p: Hip hurrah ! That 's what I call a fellow countryman .

sp.speaker: BISHOP HARDBROOKE
sp.p: You see we 're all Americans down here .

sp.speaker: SECOND STAFF MEMBER
sp.p: Now , Governor Braddock , show your stars and stripes .

lg.l: Yet you do n't seem to dwell in unity .
I recollect , and it 's not years ago ,
Receiving a petition , and a large one —
Some six or seven thousand ?

sp.speaker: GOVERNOR BRADDOCK
sp.p: Demanding a withdrawal of some troops .

sp.speaker: BISHOP HARDBROOKE
sp.p: We 're not responsible for our lower classes .

lg.l: You did n't withdraw them .

div.stage: An embarrassing silence

lg.stage: Slaps the Governor on the shoulder
lg.l: Good American !
Jesus of Nazareth was a foreigner .

sp.speaker: GOVERNOR BRADDOCK
sp.p: The Bishop would hardly say so though .

lg.l: And you ,
You , Governor , do you go before the people
With all you know ? No secrets , not a one ?

sp.speaker: BISHOP HARDBROOKE
sp.p: It eases the heart , brother , to confess .

div.stage: Points to Egerton

sp.speaker: GENERAL CHADBOURNE
sp.p: I , Colonel , get my orders from above .

div.stage: Points to the Governor
Points to Egerton

lg.l: Then come along .
I 've got some good Americans up here
Who do n't send in petitions .

div.stage: Laughter

lg.stage: As they start for the stairs
lg.l: Never you mind , gentlemen , ‘ twill not be long
Until the model that I 've built up here
Will be the model everywhere .
Hurray !

div.stage: Attracted by the shouting , some ladies look in , forward right

sp.speaker: A LADY
sp.p: They do have such good times .

div.stage: They withdraw

lg.stage: From the steps to the Butler
lg.l: I 'll be upstairs .

div.stage: Seeing the hall empty , the young people who have looked in occasionally from the conservatory , enter and take possession

lg.l: Hello , Gladys !

p.stage: Ardsley disappears after the others . Mrs. Orr enters , forward right , and is later joined by Mrs. Egerton

sp.speaker: MRS. ORR
sp.p: You surely have not spoken of this to him ?

sp.speaker: MRS. EGERTON
sp.p: The other night I started to .

div.stage: Mrs. Egerton glances back uneasily into the room

sp.speaker: MRS. ORR
sp.p: They 're all right . Let 's go here behind the pines .

lg.l: Serve them the lunch now , Charles .

div.stage: The Butler goes into the room , forward right . The two women pass left , where they are somewhat shut in by the pines

lg.l: And then — I do n't know — something in his face —
Perhaps the wonder that I knew would come
That such a thing — If people only knew —
Donald is not the hard unfeeling man —
And knowing this ——

div.stage: She hesitates

lg.l: My heart rose up and I — I simply said
That Harry had heard a sighing from the walls .
I told him so much , for it 's worried me .
And he at once ——
I know . ‘ The pines ! ’
‘ The pines ! ’ And walked the floor and laughed ;
And such a heart-free laugh I have not heard
In twenty years . ‘ The pines ! ’
He had caught the very soul
Of the forest .

sp.speaker: MRS. ORR
sp.p: And the triumph of it all !

lg.l: Ah , no one knows how many , many years
Donald has dreamed of this , how all his thought
And all his ——

div.stage: Stands regarding the young people dancing

sp.speaker: MRS. ORR
sp.p: One has but to look at it .

lg.l: Yet not for it as his , not that at all ,
But for the building of it .
And now
That it has taken form you cannot think
How like a boy he is , how eagerly
He flees here from the business of the day
And how he walks about enjoying it .
‘ Tis like the sea . When he is here alone
The burden of his great business falls away
And he is young again . I sometimes feel ,
Lying in bed at night and knowing he
Is walking here alone , the lights turned low ,
And listening for the sighing of the pines ,
That somehow ‘ tis a woman he has made
And that she whispers to him in these hours ,
Comes to him beautiful from out the pines
After his long , long wooing of her ——

sp.speaker: MRS. ORR
sp.p: I see ! Beautiful , beautiful ! I see ! I see ! It needed that one breath to make it live .

lg.l: Before it was a house ,
And now a living thing . I see ! I see !

div.stage: Kisses the little pines

lg.l: If one could only know it is not God
Whispering through the walls of our new home
Some dreadful word , and yet with voice so low .

sp.speaker: MRS. ORR
sp.p: My dear , your words are perfect Greek to me .

sp.speaker: MRS. EGERTON
sp.p: You know they say the men are suffering so . And Donald does not seem to see .

lg.l: The men ?

sp.speaker: MRS. EGERTON
sp.p: Yes ; Harry says that some are without bread . And we here — and the music and the lights .

lg.l: Why , Mary Egerton ! You do not mean —
You cannot mean that that suggested this ,
That vulgar thing , this beautiful idea !

sp.speaker: MRS. EGERTON
sp.p: If one could only help them , only help them !

lg.l: The hunger of a lot of stupid men
Who wish to tell your husband what to do ,
And he with a brain like this , and they with claws !
It all depends upon such little things ,
Things that we 've never earned ——
Harry , you say ?
That fall right at our feet we do n't know how .
The chance of birth ! What right have I to this
Who 've never done one thing to help the world ,
While they who work their lives out ——
Ca n't even have the food and clothes they need .
People have asked me why — that 's why it is
I 've done my shopping in the city lately .
You meet them in the stores and on the streets .
And they 're so thin , so worn with the long strike .
Just think of children crying for mere bread !
It 's horrible . I thought this afternoon
As I stood at the window looking out —
Through the first snow the motor cars came up .
I do n't believe they even noticed it .
It means so little to them . It 's just snow .
But in the workers ’ homes — I just can n't think
Of God as looking down with unconcern .
I could n't love Him if I thought He could .

sp.speaker: MRS. ORR
sp.p: I do n't know what we 're ever going to do .

lg.l: If only some strong , gifted man would come
And show us how , show us all how to live .
We 'd all be so much happier than we are .
I wish to goodness I could shut my ears
And never hear that ‘ Help the world ’ again .
You can n't pick up a book or magazine ,
Even a fashion journal , or go out
To see your friends , it seems ——

div.stage: The men are seen coming down the stairs , the Governor and the Bishop on either side of Egerton . They are all laughing and having a good time

lg.l: I 'm very sorry .
It is n't the place . But I 've been so distraught .
Let us go in and put it all away .
And you must never mention it . I can n't bear
To think of people talking .

sp.speaker: MRS. ORR
sp.p: Hear them laugh ! I would n't live with such a wicked man .

sp.speaker: MRS. EGERTON
sp.p: That is n't kind in you .

lg.l: In twenty years
We 'll all be wearing grave-clothes .
There 'll not be one retreat where we can go ,
We ladies of the ancien regime ;
We 'll all be out , with not a single place
Where we can make the tables ring with cards
And laugh and just be gay . Even the pines ,
The beautiful pines , are tainted , and the snow .
The winter long I 'll never dare go out .
I 'll be afraid I 'll catch this ‘ Help the world ’
And come home hearing things . You precious goose !
You just sha n't give way to this silly mood .
And at the moment when you have about you
The money and the best names in the State ;
Just everything that mortal heart can wish .
lg.stage: They watch the men coming down the steps
lg.l: You ought to be so proud .

div.stage: The piano stops

lg.l: O pshaw !
Even the Governor — do n't you see , when he 's with Donald
And when his wife 's with you , how they both show
How all they are and all they hope to be
They owe to Donald ?

sp.speaker: MRS. EGERTON
sp.p: And he 's so good , so good in many ways .

div.stage: The young people make for the conservatory

sp.speaker: MRS. ORR
sp.p: And yet so gay , so sensible with it all .

lg.l: It is n't that I 'm ungrateful , Sylvia .
I 'm never done with thanking God for all
The blessings that I have .
I can n't help wishing , though , that he would see
And do for others as he does for us .

div.stage: They stand listening

lg.l: Just let your minds go out about the mountains .
Have you had too much punch , or what 's the trouble ?

div.stage: Laughter

sp.speaker: MRS. ORR
sp.p: Just hear how joyous hearted ! Promise me ——

lg.l: He 's telling them of the pines !

lg.stage: Beckons to the Butler , who is passing
lg.l: Tell Donald that I wish to speak with ——

sp.speaker: EGERTON
sp.p: It 's something , gentlemen , that we all have need of .

lg.l: Dear , if you ever dare tell Donald this
And pass this ghastly whisper to his heart ,
I 'll be the Secret Lady of the Pines ;
I 'll whisper something . What if Donald knew
Who 's kept the strike afoot ? The great unknown
Contributor to the Citizens ’ Relief ?
Who had twelve hundred dollars in the bank ,
A present from a Christmas long ago ?
Twelve hundred and twelve hundred ——!
It 's not ; he 's checked it out . So ! If you care
Nothing for Donald 's happiness , I do .

div.stage: She leaves Mrs. Egerton standing near the pines . Other ladies have begun to come in

lg.stage: With a strange smile , calling back
lg.l: I really will .

sp.speaker: GENERAL CHADBOURNE
sp.p: He 's waiting , gentlemen , till he finds the mine .

lg.l: That 's why I can n't
Take you down now . But when I find the mine
And get the gold to puddling in the pots ,
If I can find me plastic metal workers
That I can mould and hammer while they mould
And hammer out my vision on the walls ,
I 'll show you through some subterranean chambers
Will set your eyes a-dazzle . In the dark ,
Lit by the torches in the miners ’ caps ,
You 'll see the world of metals moving up
Through human hands as here you see the tree .
That 's why my basement is n't finished yet .

div.stage: He leaves the group and comes forward

lg.l: Call them in , Charles . Have all of them come in .

sp.speaker: GOVERNOR BRADDOCK
sp.p: Metals , then trees , then mills , then books and pictures .

sp.speaker: BISHOP HARDBROOKE
sp.p: Raw matter on its spiral up to spirit .

div.stage: Ladies come in , centre and forward right

lg.l: Come right in .
If you 'll allow me , friends , suppose you stand
Where you can have my forest in your eye .
lg.stage: He arranges them to face right
lg.l: I do n't see , ladies , how you ever endure
The dulness of these males . We 've been at riddles .
Come in . I 've kept my best wine for the last .
lg.stage: He steps back near the door , centre right
lg.l: Suppose you 'd made an Adam out of clay ,
Worked years to get it to your satisfaction ,
And now you 're looking at it , hands all washed
And mind confronting , weighing what 's been done .
Suddenly you 're aware of something standing by you
That whispers in your left ear : ‘ Make a wish
Within the power of God . ’ What would it be ?

sp.speaker: BISHOP HARDBROOKE
sp.p: To see it walk about the garden , brother .

lg.l: Suppose your Adam was a pine-wood , Bishop ,
That could n't walk .
Then just to hear it breathe .
A woman 's intuition !
lg.stage: Looks to see who it is
lg.l: Sylvia Orr !
An old friend of mine .
lg.stage: He gives a signal to some one
lg.l: A clear day in the pine-wood .

div.stage: Suddenly the hall is beautifully illuminated

lg.l: With clouds ,
The dawn just breaking .
lg.stage: The hall becomes gray and shadowy
lg.l: Ancient silence .
Donald !

div.stage: The silence is broken by the ringing of a telephone bell in the room forward left

lg.l: Do n't you dare !

div.stage: The Butler goes out to answer the telephone

sp.speaker: GOVERNOR BRADDOCK
sp.p: This age of bells and whistles .

lg.stage: Comes forward and takes his stand near the door forward left
lg.l: Just in time !
They do n't concern me . We are far away
With quiet all about us and the woods .

div.stage: The silence is intense

lg.l: ... And it gives me pleasure to announce to you
Upon the occasion of the opening
Of your new mansion , Colonel Egerton ,
This bit of news , sir , from the military ;
And I offer it with our congratulations :
The strike is over ;
The men have yielded and have gone to work .
And all 's been done without one ——

div.stage: Enter the Butler hurriedly

lg.l: For Mr. Egerton .

p.stage: In a low voice over the crowd

sp.speaker: Mr. Egerton !
sp.p: GENERAL CHADBOURNE . Is n't that Captain Haskell ?

div.stage: Egerton comes forward , making his way through the crowd
The Butler goes to him and they talk

lg.stage: Calls after Egerton as he goes out left
lg.l: Good luck !
This probably ends it .

sp.speaker: GOVERNOR BRADDOCK
sp.p: What 's your opinion of these mysteries , Bishop ?

sp.speaker: BISHOP HARDBROOKE
sp.p: I 'm one of those that simply stand and wait .

sp.speaker: GOVERNOR BRADDOCK
sp.p: You do n't believe in modern miracles .

lg.l: There are miracles and miracles , Governor Braddock .
I try to keep elastic in these things ,
Steering a middle course with open mind .
Needed just this to crown the time we 're having .
We are living in an age in many ways
Without a parallel . I sometimes think —
If I may say it not too seriously —
Of those last days we read of when the world
Goes on its way unconscious of the end .
We give and take in marriage , eat and drink ,
And meet our friends in social intercourse ,
And all the while a Spirit walks beside us ,
Enters our homes and writes upon our walls .
There are whispers everywhere if we could hear them ;
And some of them grow louder with the days ;
And pools of quiet ruffle and show storms .
You , Governor , feel the popular unrest
As it manifests itself in politics ,
The shift of parties and of principles ,
Rocks that we used to think would never change .
And brother Egerton in industry ;
He feels it .

sp.speaker: EGERTON
sp.p: Appearing at the door , excited , and keeping back so as not to be seen by the peopleChadbourne !

div.stage: The General joins him and they disappear

lg.l: I sincerely hope
We 're on the eve , however , of a day
When trouble-makers in the ranks of Labor ,
Not only here in Foreston but elsewhere ,
May find it to their interest to respect ,
Nay , reverence as a thing ordained by God ,
The right of men to earn their daily bread ,
As well as profitable to obey the laws
Without the unseemly presence of armed men .

div.stage: There is a clapping of hands . General Chadbourne appears just inside the door and beckons to Ardsley , who goes in to him

lg.l: And I will take occasion here and now
To say what you 've been thinking all this while ,
And in the presence of the man himself :
We are fortunate , my friends ——

p.stage: Appears and calls to one of the guests farther back

lg.l: BISHOP HARDBROOKE .
In having at the helm of our great State
One who loves order more than he loves votes .

div.stage: General clapping of hands

lg.stage: In a low voice over the crowd
lg.l: Governor !

div.stage: The Governor bows

lg.l: My friends ,
I quite agree with the Bishop .

sp.speaker: GOVERNOR BRADDOCK
sp.p: I do n't mean in his estimate of me .

div.stage: More laughter . The Governor catches sight of the guest beckoning to him

sp.speaker: GOVERNOR BRADDOCK
sp.p: But here 's my better half . You might ask her . Pardon me till I see ——

lg.stage: Calls urgently to the Bishop in a voice that is barely heard
lg.l: Go on ! Go on !
Society , my friends , is like this house ,
This mansion that we all so much admire .

div.stage: Ardsley stands impassive till the Governor has gone out and the Bishop has again got the attention of the people , then goes quickly into the side room

lg.l: Imagine what a state of things we 'd have
If every wooden fellow in these walls ,
Not only here but in the mill upstairs ,
Should lend his heart to tongues of discontent
Until his very tools became a burden .
Very true . Where would this be ,
This beautiful thing that Colonel Egerton
Has built with so much labor and so much taste ?
And out there in the world where we all dwell ,
Where all of us have places in the walls ,
Some working with their hands on farms , in mines ;
Some building ; some at forges ; at machines
Weaving our garments ; others more endowed
Loaned to us from the higher planes of being ,
Men of the Over-Soul , inventors , dreamers ,
Planners of longer railroads , bigger mills ,
The great preparers for the finer souls
That build the dome , the finishers of things ,
Prophets of God , musicians , artists , poets ,
As we 've all seen how Colonel Egerton
In his third story has his books and pictures —
Suppose a bitter wind of discontent
Should shake the great walls of this social order ,
Set the first story men against the second ,
The second against the third , until the mass ,
Throwing their tools down on the world 's great floor ,
Should clamor up the dome for pens and brushes ,
Shutting their eyes to the cold facts of life
That we climb up Life 's ladder by degrees —

div.stage: His attention is attracted for a moment to a group of men that has been collecting forward centre , evidently concerned with whatever it is that is going on in the side room

lg.l: But I 'm afraid , my friends ——

sp.speaker: BISHOP HARDBROOKE
sp.p: I 'm wasting good material for a sermon .

div.stage: Laughter

lg.l: Is n't he just too bright for anything !
What 's up ?
To come home to the task
That brother Egerton lays upon our ears .
We have all of us read stories and seen things .

div.stage: Laughter
General laughter

Mrs. Egerton , who , since the ringing of the telephone bell , has shown an increasing anxiety as to the message that has come , unable longer to contain herself , comes hurriedly forward through the people

sp.speaker: BISHOP HARDBROOKE
sp.p: Do n't let us scare you , sister Egerton .

div.stage: Laughter . The people turn just in time to see Governor Braddock , General Chadbourne , and Ralph Ardsley with overcoats on and hats in their hands , stealing across to get out forward right . Mrs. Egerton hurries into the room from which they came
The three go out

sp.speaker: VOICES
sp.p: What 's the matter ? What 's the matter ?

sp.speaker: PALE LADY
sp.p: It 's something terrible , I know it is .

sp.speaker: LADY IN BLACK
sp.p: We always have to pay for our good times .

div.stage: George Egerton and Gladys Egerton come quickly from the conservatory and enter the side room

lg.l: I should n't wonder if those horrid strikers
Were burning the mill .

sp.speaker: LADY IN BLACK
sp.p: Or may be some one 's hurt .

lg.l: Please tell us what 's the trouble .

div.stage: A silence

lg.l: It has been suggested , friends , in view of this
Personal something that has happened here —
I do n't know what it is , but we all know
In trouble how we like to be alone .
Later I 'll call them up and for us all
Extend our sympathy when we know the cause .

div.stage: There is a movement of people departing

sp.speaker: LADY WITH THE CONSPICUOUS COIFFURE
sp.p: ‘ Twas more like anger ; did n't you see his face ?

sp.speaker: LADY IN BLACK
sp.p: When everything was so , so beautiful !

div.stage: They vanish with the other guests . A minute or so later the Butler enters , right rear , and walks as though dazed through the empty hall

lg.l: Charlie !
What is it ?
Trouble at the mill .
Gone !
Father , they 've gone !
Look in the rooms .

div.stage: Goes rear

lg.stage: Looks in the room forward right
lg.l: They 've gone !
Chester ! Marjorie ! Well , I 'll be damned !

sp.speaker: GLADYS EGERTON
sp.p: I hate him , O I hate him !

sp.speaker: GLADYS EGERTON
sp.p: What will we ever do ! Just think of it !

lg.l: Why do you stand that way ?
lg.stage: Comes to the door forward left
lg.l: O do shut up ,
Mother .

div.stage: Donald Egerton comes in , putting on his overcoat

lg.l: Remember , Donald , he 's our son .

sp.speaker: GEORGE EGERTON
sp.p: Always defending him ! You make me sick .

lg.l: You 've always said you never in your life
Lost hold upon yourself .
Tell Jack to bring the car to the front door .

div.stage: The Butler goes out centre right

sp.speaker: GEORGE EGERTON
sp.p: Wait , father , till I get my ——

div.stage: Starts for the room forward left

lg.l: If he 's done it —
He has some reason , Donald . And you know
Jergens has never liked him .

div.stage: Harry Egerton comes in right rear , his hat and shoulders covered with snow
She hurries to him and embraces him
George Egerton reappears

sp.speaker: GLADYS EGERTON
sp.p: I just hate you ! You selfish thing ! See what you 've done !

lg.l: He 's very sorry , sister .

sp.speaker: HARRY EGERTON
sp.p: I had n't the least intention , father ——

sp.speaker: MRS. EGERTON
sp.p: What is it you 've done , Harry ?

lg.stage: To the Butler and the Maids who have appeared at the doors
lg.l: Get away from there !

div.stage: Egerton Tosses His Overcoat Into the Side Room

lg.l: Harry , is it true
You kept the men from going back to work ?

sp.speaker: HARRY EGERTON
sp.p: I wanted to have a talk with father first .

lg.l: There !
All my life
I 've wanted to say something to you , father ;
Especially since I went to work . You once ,
When I came home from college , you remember ,
And had n't made my mind up what to do ,
What my life work should be ——
We talked together and you said that now
Three things lay open to me , that I could choose
And that you 'd back me up . First , there was Art .
And though you did n't say so , I could see
You 'd have been glad if I had chosen that .
I had a talent for it , so you said ,
And I could study with the best of them .
You 'd set aside a hundred thousand dollars ;
And I could finish up by travelling ,
Seeing the beautiful buildings of the world ;
That I could take my time , then settle down
And glorify my land : that 's what you said .
Then there was Public Life . You 'd start me in
By giving me the Courier . That , you said ,
Would give me at once a standing among men
And training in political affairs .
And that if I made good you 'd see to it
I had a seat in Congress , and in the end
That probably I 'd be Governor of the State .
And then you paused . You did n't like the third .
Business , you said , was an unpleasant life .
‘ Twas all right as you 'd used it , as a means ,
But as an end — And then you used words , father ,
That changed my life although you did n't know it —
‘ Business , my son , is war ; needful at times ,
But as a life ,— you shook your head and sighed .
With that we ended it , for some one came
And I went out . Six years ago last June ,
The seventh of June ; I can n't forget the day .
The sun was shining but a strange new light
Lay over everything . All of a sudden
It dawned upon my mind that I 'd been reared
Inside a garden full of flowers and trees ,
And only now had chanced upon the gate
And stepped out . There was smoke upon the skies
And a rumbling of strange wagons in the street .
I was afraid . For every man I met
Seemed just about to ask , ‘ What side are you on ? ’
And I was twenty-one and did n't know .

sp.speaker: EGERTON
sp.p: You seem to have found out since you 've been away .

lg.l: I 'd always thought ‘ twas garden everywhere .
I walked on up the river and sat down
Upon the logs up there , and night came on .
And in the waters flowing at my feet
The lighted land went by , cities and towns
And the vast murmur and the daily life
Of those that toil , the hunger and the care .
And in my heart I knew that it was true ,
That what you said was true . And I came back
Filled with such peace as I had never known .
‘ I 'll enter business , father . ’ And I did .
I started at the bottom in the mill
Helping the engineer , and from the saws
Carried the lumber with the other men .
Then in the yard . You always praised my work .
I 'm in the office now at twenty-seven ,
And Secretary of the Company .
I think I know the business pretty well .
You 've said so . But somehow ——

div.stage: He pauses

lg.l: In Public Life , if I had chosen that ,
And after six years ’ work that you approved ,
If one day I had come ——
‘ Father , I can n't go on ; my way is blocked
And all my hopes are falling to the ground . ’
There 's nothing , not one thing you would n't have done .
Or if I had a building half way up ,
My masterpiece , a mighty capitol
That finished would be known throughout the land ,
And I had met with interference , men
Who had no vision — you know what I mean —
And I had come to you , ‘ Father , I 'm thwarted , ’
O I can see with one sweep of your hand
How you would clear the skies .
Listen to me !
For probably in all my life I 'll never
Speak to you as I 'm speaking now , my father .
In these six years for one cause or another
There 've been three strikes that have cost the Company thousands
In money , to say nothing of those things
That all the money in the world can n't buy .
Now let me ask , my father , if this loss ,
Instead of springing from these strikes , had come
Through breakdowns of the machinery , or in the camps
Through failure to get the timber out in time ,
Would n't you have dismissed the man in charge ?
Then why do you let Jergens run the mill ?
Has n't he failed , and miserably , with the men ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE EGERTON
sp.p: What have you to do with it ?

div.stage: George Egerton walks away and stands by the pine trees , picking off and biting the needles

lg.l: Is it because the earnings have increased ?
Think what it 's cost you , father . In every mill
Jergens has touched he 's left a cursing there
That 's all come back on us . Why , my father ,
Our name 's become a by-word through the State ,
‘ As hard as Egerton . ’ And when I think
Of what might be , the good-will and the peace ,
The happiness ! There 's not the least excuse
For this cut in wages , father , and you know it .
You can n't help but know it . You 've the books ;
You know what you 've been making . But that aside :
To come to what I would say : You 've won this strike .
You have the men in your power and you can say ,
‘ Go back , ’ and they 'll go back . But you wo n't do it .

sp.speaker: HARRY EGERTON
sp.p: Will you , when you know you 're wrong ? When you know you 're losing friends who love what 's right ? Think of the sentiment against you , father . No , father , you do n't know what 's going on .

lg.l: If you knew how they live
And the hard time they have to get along .
It is n't fair , my father , it is n't fair .
Yes , you do n't care .
Father , you love this land .
There 's never been a day in all your life ,
If there 'd been war , you would n't have closed the mill
And gone and died upon the field of battle
If the country had called to you in her need .
And I can see you how you 'd scorn the man ,
If he were serving as a General ,
Who 'd keep his rank and file as poorly fed
And ragged as he could .

div.stage: The telephone bell rings

lg.l: They 're calling up
To know about it !

lg.stage: Starts for the room , then stops
lg.l: What shall I tell them , father ?

sp.speaker: GLADYS EGERTON
sp.p: O have them come back , papa , have them come back !

lg.l: Tell them what you please .

div.stage: George goes out

lg.l: Tell them it 's all right , brother , that it 's nothing .

sp.speaker: HARRY EGERTON
sp.p: Give him his price and let him go his way ——

lg.l: A misunderstanding .
And let me run the mill .
And let us see , my father , you and I ,
If we can n't make that place of work down there
As famous for its harmony as this house .
A land is not its timber but its people ,
And not its Art , my father , but its men .
Let 's try to make this town a place of peace
And helpfulness . What do you say , my father ?

div.stage: Gladys goes into the room

lg.l: Donald ——

sp.speaker: MRS. EGERTON
sp.p: You 've asked me why it is I cannot sleep . It 's that , Donald , it 's that ! Give him the mill . They 're human beings , Donald , like ourselves .

lg.l: I had hoped , my father ,
That things would so arrange themselves that I —
That you would make me manager of the mill .

sp.speaker: MRS. EGERTON
sp.p: Donald , it 's your nobler self you hear .

sp.speaker: EGERTON
sp.p: Looks at him a long timeWhat a fool ——Turns awaywhat a fool I 've been !

div.stage: Walks about

lg.l: The mine ! Father !
The mine ! A rumor that the mine 's been found !

sp.speaker: GEORGE EGERTON
sp.p: I do n't know . They 're on the wire .

div.stage: Egerton goes out
Brother and sister wait near the door , tense , listening

lg.l: Everything !
George ,
Think of the things we 'll have !

p.stage: Turns and looks at Harry , whose face shows the sadness he feels at his father 's refusal

lg.l: Yes , mother .
Mother ——

div.stage: Distant cannon are heard

lg.l: The mine ! the mine !
Father has found the mine !

div.stage: Further booming is heard

sp.speaker: GEORGE EGERTON
sp.p: There go the guns ! They 're celebrating , father !

div.stage: He starts for the stairs and goes bounding up three steps at a time

lg.l: We 'll have them back and announce it ! We 'll have them back !
Now , now you see !
I 'll have my car now , wo n't I , daddy , daddy ?

div.stage: She disappears into the room , forward left

lg.l: I knew it ! O I knew that He would come !
lg.stage: Turns upon her son a look of awe
lg.l: Harry ! Harry !

sp.speaker: HARRY EGERTON
sp.p: The ground is white with snow .

div.stage: Egerton appears in the doorway and stands looking at his son

lg.l: What is it , papa ? What 's the matter , daddy ?
They 've run the flag up on the Court House , father !

sp.speaker: HARRY EGERTON
sp.p: I 'll mortgage the mine and pay you , father .

sp.speaker: EGERTON
sp.p: And if I do n't you 'll back the men , eh ?

div.stage: She backs toward George , who has come down the stairs

sp.speaker: HARRY EGERTON
sp.p: I 'll pay you twice its value , father .

lg.l: What !

div.stage: Egerton drops his eyes for a moment and stands as though in deep thought

lg.l: I hate you !
Big man !
George ,
Get Jergens .
Mill-hand !

div.stage: Goes out left

lg.l: Tell him to lock the mill
And have this notice tacked up on the gate ,
‘ Closed for a year . ’
Father , you 'll remember in the years to be
How I came to you one November day
And asked your help to give this country peace .
Think of it !
I 'll show you
How you can buy me and my property !
Property was made for men .
And do n't you ever
Darken that door !
And you can n't keep it idle
While men depend upon it for their bread .

div.stage: He goes out

lg.l: You dare to lay your hands upon that mill !

div.stage: He stands staring at the door

lg.l: It was n't our son ! It was n't our son !

div.stage: The cannon are heard in volley upon volley as of a town giving itself up to celebration

lg.l: Tell him to go right down , that probably
There 'll be an attack upon it .
Think of it !
That gleam about his brow ! And now he 's gone !

div.stage: She wanders back in the hall as in a dream

sp.speaker: EGERTON
sp.p: And to see Chadbourne —— Are you listening ?

lg.l: To Chadbourne that he has authority from me —
From Egerton , to treat them all alike .
What have you done , Donald !
That I expect
The mill defended , let it cost what may .

sp.speaker: GLADYS EGERTON
sp.p: I hate him , O I hate him !

lg.stage: Who has come forward and stands facing him
lg.l: What have you done !

div.head: ACT IV

stage.head: THE LIVING MILL
stage.stage: Scene : Inside the mill , showing in front a sort of half storeroom , half office shut in from the main body of the mill by a railing in the centre of which is a gate that swings in and out . Far back in this main body of the mill one sees a number of great gang saws from which off-carriers , with freshly sawed slabs and lumber upon their rollers , branch right from the main line that runs the full length of the mill . Through an opening in the far end , whence the logs are drawn up an incline to the saws , one sees as through a telescope a portion of the river and of the mountains on the opposite bank . Up toward the front , left , in this main body of the mill is a wide door that opens outside . In the foreground , within the space partitioned off by the railing , a pair of stairs , evidently connecting with the outdoors on the ground floor , comes up rear left . Centre , against this left wall , a pole six or eight inches in diameter , and to all appearances only recently set , goes up through a hole in the roof . Upon the floor at the foot of the pole , from which two long ropes hang down , lies a large American flag partially strung upon the rope . Forward from the pole is a door which apparently is no longer in use , a strip being nailed across it . About this end of the enclosure are piles of window sash and kegs of nails . Centre rear , at right angles to the side walls , so that one sitting upon a stool may look back into the mill , is a long checkers ’ desk with two or three stools before it and with the usual litter of papers , books , and a telephone upon it . In the right wall , rear , where one coming up the stairs may walk straight on and enter , is a door connecting with the main office .

As the Scene opens , something very important seems to be going on in this main office . A crowd of men , workmen and militiamen together , are packed about the door , intent upon whatever it is that is transpiring inside . Forward , away from the crowd , a small group , mostly of militiamen , is gathered about two guards with rifles in their hands , who have evidently just come in . Back , beyond the railing and close to the crowd , a group of workmen about Wes Dicey is engaged in a heated argument . And farther back in the mill , especially about the large door , left , are bodies of men talking together . As the Scene opens , and for a few minutes afterwards , some one up the pole is heard singing .
Time : Saturday afternoon the week following the preceding Act .

lg.stage: Comes from the crowd to the militiamen
lg.l: Servin ’ the papers on the mine , you think ?

sp.speaker: MILITIAMAN
sp.p: He 's too damn proud to play the constable .

sp.speaker: THIRD MILITIAMAN
sp.p: To Fourth Militiaman , who has just come up the stairs with his shoulders hung with knapsacksChadbourne 's here .

sp.speaker: SECOND WORKMAN
sp.p: Egerton makes no terms till he 's on top .

sp.speaker: FIFTH MILITIAMAN
sp.p: He 'll have his hands full . Seen the evening papers ?

div.stage: He unfolds a paper and a group gathers about him

lg.l: That 's right ! that 's right !

lg.stage: From the edge of the crowd
lg.l: What are they sayin ’ , Mike ?

lg.stage: On the edge of the crowd , looking toward the group about Dicey
lg.l: We can n't hear nothin ’ with that racket there .

sp.speaker: FIRST MILITIAMAN
sp.p: It 's his lost sheep he 's after .

sp.speaker: FOURTH WORKMAN
sp.p: You 've stood by us , boys , and we 'll stand by you .

lg.l: Tell him we wo n't , no matter what he says !

div.stage: The Sixth Militiaman comes up the stairs , with four or five bugles , and shows surprise to see the crowd gathered

lg.stage: In the group about the paper
lg.l: And Smith and Balding Brothers !

sp.speaker: FIFTH MILITIAMAN
sp.p: Give him a rouse . What say you . One , two , three .

lg.l: Hurrah for the Living Mill !
A GENERAL SHOUT .
The Living Mill !

sp.speaker: FIFTH MILITIAMAN
sp.p: I guess , by God , he knows where we stand now .

div.stage: They join the crowd about the door . Jim King comes through the gate in the railing , followed by Rome Masters , who is considerably intoxicated

sp.speaker: JIM KING
sp.p: And hug ‘ em round the neck , if I was you . That 's what I 'd do .

sp.speaker: ROME MASTERS
sp.p: Now you just stop that , Jim .

sp.speaker: JIM KING
sp.p: Why did you tell Aug. Jergens that you would ?

sp.speaker: ROME MASTERS
sp.p: I ai n't said nothin ’ about backin ’ down . But I ai n't nothin ’ agin him .

lg.l: There you go !
It does beat hell . You just keep saying that ,
That you ai n't nothin ’ agin him , and you 'll see .
Who 's to be judge what 's for the Public Good ?

sp.speaker: ROME MASTERS
sp.p: I ai n't said that I would n't do the job .

lg.stage: Stands on tip-toe and looks over the crowd , then turns back to Masters
lg.l: Did n't you think and did n't I think and Wes
That when they cut the pie we 'd get our share ,
One big long table with no head and tail
But all the boys the same , and everything
Piled on it and divided ?

div.stage: The group about Dicey become more noisy

lg.l: Put him out !

div.stage: Dicey comes from the centre of the group and catches sight of King , who beckons to him

lg.l: If you do n't like it , Wes , why do n't you leave ?
Why in the hell do n't you leave ? We 're free men .

div.stage: Dicey , King and Masters walk over to the pile of sash , left

lg.l: Offer ‘ em coppers for their Union cards .

sp.speaker: FOURTH WORKMAN
sp.p: And where 's the mine that you was goin ’ to share ?

sp.speaker: FIFTH WORKMAN
sp.p: You want old Egerton to have it , eh ?

lg.l: Bring on the Constitution and let 's vote !
Do n't use that name .
Let 's have no trouble , men .
This ai n't no time to quarrel among ourselves .
Try to remember , boys , it 's his name , too .

div.stage: Suddenly there is a tremendous cheering by those about the door . A militiaman hurries from the crowd , grabs a bugle from the Sixth Militiaman and , darting out centre , starts to blow it

lg.l: Do n't do that ! Here !
Do n't do that !

div.stage: The crowd begins to break up , many of the men climbing back over the railing into the mill proper

lg.l: What 's the trouble ?
They 're out for their selves , damn ‘ em ; we 'll be too .

lg.stage: Coming away with two or three others
lg.l: Young Egerton 's pure gold if ever was .

sp.speaker: WES DICEY
sp.p: Do n't make no move , though , Jim , till we see first .

div.stage: He separates himself from the other two , and they mingle with the men

sp.speaker: EIGHTH MILITIAMAN
sp.p: That 's just the way they did the old man 's farm . We had a place and did n't want to sell . That made no difference . Eminent Domain . ‘ Out of the way there , home ! ’

lg.l: What did he say ?
Then if the Company can take men 's lands
To build their railroads through ——
And if you say the Law 's the same for all ,
Then why can n't we take theirs when we need bread ?
Be smoking when he comes out .
What Egerton wants , that 's for the Public Good !

sp.speaker: CHRIS KNUDSON
sp.p: There , there you 're not remembering it again !

div.stage: General Chadbourne comes from the office , followed by Captain Haskell , and after these Harry Egerton , Sam Williams , Harvey Anderson , Buck Bentley , and others . The militiamen make a big smoke

sp.speaker: GENERAL CHADBOURNE
sp.p: You 'll not lay hands on property in this State .

lg.l: The right of men to work is just as sacred
As is the right of property , General Chadbourne ,
And more important to the general welfare .

sp.speaker: GENERAL CHADBOURNE
sp.p: These gates have stood wide open here for weeks .

sp.speaker: WORKMEN
sp.p: That 's the point ; on whose terms ?

sp.speaker: GENERAL CHADBOURNE
sp.p: Of course you 'd like to make the terms yourselves .

sp.speaker: HARRY EGERTON
sp.p: What would you have men do ?

lg.l: You say the State 's been fair with them . All right .
But it ai n't the State that feeds them , it 's the Mill ;
And it ai n't the State that clothes them , it 's the Mill ;
And it ai n't the State they think of when they think
Of better homes hereafter , it 's the Mill .
And there ai n't no fairness that ai n't fair in here ,
And there ai n't no freedom that ai n't free in here ,
Though there ai n't no use of saying that to you .

lg.stage: Ignoring Anderson , as he does throughout
lg.l: Employers have the right
To buy their labor in the open market ,
And if you fellows here can n't meet the price ——
You 'd have us starve ?
You 'll have to step aside
And give way to some stronger men that can
And you expect men to obey a law
That gives no hope of anything but this ?
You 'd been to work and you 'd been satisfied
If some outsiders had n't come along
And fired your ignorant minds .

div.stage: Murmurs in the crowd

lg.l: Land o ’ the free !
We are all of us outsiders in a way ,
Yourself as well as Harvey here and I .
But in a way there 's no such thing . We 're men ,
And that which injures one injures us all .

sp.speaker: GENERAL CHADBOURNE
sp.p: I 'm here on duty ; quite a different thing .

lg.l: What I have done I have done not without cause
Nor hastily .
You know yourself these men
Would have been to work .

sp.speaker: SAM WILLIAMS
sp.p: If it had n't been for Mr. Egerton .

sp.speaker: HARRY EGERTON
sp.p: For this , I am . But for conditions here ——

sp.speaker: Remember that
sp.p: WORKMEN . No ! We ! We seized the mill !

sp.speaker: BUCK BENTLEY
sp.p: It was we unlocked the gates .

sp.speaker: WORKMEN
sp.p: But we marched in , so we 're responsible .

lg.l: We wo n't dispute about who did it , partners .
There 's glory enough for all .
I 'm in it too .

div.stage: He laughs

lg.l: But for conditions that produced this strike
God knows and I know it was not these men .
I only wish that that was farther off .

sp.speaker: GENERAL CHADBOURNE
sp.p: If wrong 's been done there 's legal remedies .

sp.speaker: HARRY EGERTON
sp.p: Conditions , General , that outreach the law .

lg.l: Who makes the law ?
Their legal right to buy the cheapest men
And drive them just as hard and just as long
As they can stand it .
That 's right !

sp.speaker: WORKMEN
sp.p: No troops for us ! No troops for us !

div.stage: This cry is caught up by the crowd and is carried on back through the mill . Chadbourne looks at the militiamen and unbuttons his overcoat and feels about in his pockets

lg.l: Pardon me , General , if I speak right out ,
But I 've seen wages lowered to buy lands ,
And I 've seen bread taken from these men here
To gamble with . There are some things , General Chadbourne ,
That can n't go on . We 've but one life to live
And we just can n't stand by and see some things
And live . It 's not worth while , it 's not worth while .
And while you 're here I want to say a word ,
For possibly we wo n't see you any more ,
And they 'll be asking of us up the State .
I never thought of it ——
Take down their names .
Till Mr. Egerton made his talk that day ;
But it 's a fact and it stares you in the face :
When Companies are wronged , or think they are ,
They touch the wires and the troops are sent ,
But when the men are wronged , or think they are ,
It 's ‘ legal remedies . ’
FIRST GUARD .
I
Guess you know me .

sp.speaker: SECOND MILITIAMAN
sp.p: And you can take mine , too .

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: Who ever saw the like of this before !

lg.l: A hundred years from now
They 'll write them in the larger book of Fame .

sp.speaker: FOURTH MILITIAMAN
sp.p: This is the third time we 've been out this year .

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: You look like Israel Putnam and Paul Jones .

lg.l: We came down here to see the square thing done ;
But it 's got to work both ways .
You 're all right , partner , only you do n't see
The inside of this thing that 's happened here .
The day 's gone by when two or three big men
Could ride her to and fro for their own gain
And lay her up and starve the crew . That 's past .
We 're going to take the flags down of the Kings ,
Kings of Lumber , Kings of Cotton , Kings of Coal ,
From one end to the other of this land ,
And we 'll all be Americans , North and South
And East and West until you touch the seas .
And there 's the thing that 's going to fly the mast .
lg.stage: Points to the flag on the floor
lg.l: And when she climbs you 'll hear the guns go off
Announcing a new Independence here .

div.stage: Tremendous cheering
Two militiamen are seen coming up the stairs , the one loaded with blankets , the other with ten or twelve rifles

lg.l: And this is final , eh ?
We 'll hold the mill !

lg.stage: Catching sight of the two militiamen
lg.l: And the mine too ! That 's right ! And the mine too !

div.stage: Tremendous cheering

lg.l: If you have any way to guarantee
That these men who have worked here many years
And faithfully , as I know , will have their right
To work respected and at an honest wage ,
And that while there are profits to be shared
There 'll be no starving time among these men ——
Do n't think because you 're Mr. Egerton
That you 're immune . You 'll find the laws the same
Whether you 're Mr. Egerton or not .
If need be I 'll call out ten thousand men .
Bring on the Constitution and let 's vote !
You 'll have your hands full if reports are true .

sp.speaker: HARRY EGERTON
sp.p: We none of us can tell what men will do . The times are changing and the days bring light .

sp.speaker: GENERAL CHADBOURNE
sp.p: You mean you 'll stir up mutiny again ?

sp.speaker: HARRY EGERTON
sp.p: I 'll see they get the truth , then let them choose . That is a right we all have , General Chadbourne .

sp.speaker: GENERAL CHADBOURNE
sp.p: You 'll have no chance to see them .

div.stage: Goes down the stairs , the two guards leading the way

lg.l: Very well .
Just say to Governor Braddock it 's with him .
We 'll keep right on at work . The gates shall be
Open and the men shall come and go .

lg.stage: To two militiamen who are busy stringing the flag on the rope
lg.l: Damn pretty men you are to raise a flag .
You ought to have a red one .

sp.speaker: SECOND MILITIAMAN
sp.p: We 'll see what kind of men dare take it down .

div.stage: Disappears down the stairs . There is a movement of the workmen back into the mill

lg.l: Now let 's to work !

div.stage: The militiamen gather left , and to some of them the rifles , knapsacks , etc ., are distributed . Buck Bentley , who has taken the bugles in his hands , walks to and fro

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: You 'd better be off , Bentley , do n't you think ? They 'll turn Hell upside down to get that mine .

sp.speaker: BUCK BENTLEY
sp.p: He wanted to say something to me .

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: Calls rear left to Harry Egerton , who is engaged with Dicey , a number of workmen being gathered about themPartner !

div.stage: They stand silent , watching the group

lg.stage: Leaving the group and passing rear , calls to Anderson
lg.l: The same old sore .

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: You 've noticed any change these past few days ?

lg.l: In Egerton , you mean ? Ai n't it the strain
Of breaking with his family ?

div.stage: Harry Egerton starts toward them , but Dicey keeps after him , the men following

sp.speaker: BUCK BENTLEY
sp.p: To Anderson , who has turned aside and half pulled from his inside pocket a legal looking documentWhat ——

lg.l: It 's a new day , my friend , a glorious day .
‘ Twill soon be night !
Try to forget the past
And everything except that we are men
Working together for the good of all .

sp.speaker: WES DICEY
sp.p: That ai n't the point though , Mr. Egerton .

lg.l: You 've got your vote , Wes , same as we have ours ,
You and your friends have . Why ai n't that enough ?
Or is it that you think the few should rule ?
There 's got to be good feelin ’ all around
If it 's to hold together as you say ;
It 's got to be plumbed well . And I do n't see ,
If it 's to be a workers ’ commonwealth ,
How you can keep the mine out . Course it 's yours
And in a way you can do as you please ,
That is , if you was like most men you could ;
But bein ’ different , standin ’ for the right ,
We do n't just see how you can say ‘ We 'll keep
The mine out and devote it to the Cause . ’
If the boys ai n't the Cause , tell us what is .
Maybe it 's as we 're ignorant and do n't know .
Please do not put things in this bitter way .
The Cause is what you 've fought for all these years ,
A chance to live a freer , larger life .
But in this struggle are you men alone ?
And shall we as we climb to better things
Reach down no help to others , but hold fast
To all we get ?
Another point . For years and years we 've had
A Union here , and when the fight came on ,
‘ Twas as a Union that we made the fight .
And Sam knows this is true , ‘ twas not so much
The cut in wages , though , that took our strength ,
As ‘ twas their breakin ’ of the Union up
As made us say ‘ By God , we 'll fight or die . ’
Ai n't that true , boys ?
And then you come
And took the stand you did as they 'd no right
To make slaves of us , closin ’ of the gates
To make us knuckle down . And you said ‘ Come , ’
And the boys followed you , and here they are .
And many of ‘ em , if I sound ‘ em right ,
Are wonderin ’ what we 're here for . I 'll ask Sam
If he 's in favor of the Open Shop .
We formed our Union , Wes , when we were slaves ,
Same as in war times armies are called out .
But when the war is over they go back .
We 've no foe now
Except ourselves .
All of which means you 'll vote
In favor of admittin ’ every man
To full rights here .
If it 's the soldier boys you 're knocking at ,
They do n't intend to stay , most of them do n't .
But as I think they 'll be invited to .
Did n't they leave their Union ?
I mean to vote , Wes , for that Living Mill
That Mr. Egerton has told us of .
For that 's the thing , or something like that thing ,
We 've worked for all these years . And now it 's come ,
A place where we can work and be free men ,
Having a say in things , as Harvey says ,
God help us if we can n't get on as friends .

div.stage: Jim King takes Dicey aside , where Masters joins them

lg.stage: Coming to Bentley and the militiamen
lg.l: I want to thank you , Bentley , and you men ,
I want to thank you for the help you 've been .
You 've played the noblest part I ever knew .
No . We have interests here ,
The rest of us have interests here ; we 've homes
And families , and the fight was ours . But you ,
You 'd never seen a one of us before .
And you came here honorable men , and now
You 're traitors through the State , and mutineers .

sp.speaker: HARRY EGERTON
sp.p: Yes , indeed , it is all right .

lg.l: You 've helped to make the history of this land ,
And there 's not one of you will not be known
And honored for it .
And now a little toast before you go .
Bentley , Kelley , Stamper , and you all ,
Sam , and you , Harvey , Chris , and Mike , and Wes ,
You 'll join us , you and Jim and Rome ?

div.stage: The three remain aside talking together

lg.l: And you ,
And you back there , you of the Living Mill —
For all time , shall we say it ?

lg.stage: With a swift glance toward Dicey , King and Masters
lg.l: And give our lives , if need be , for this thing ?

sp.speaker: SUBDUED VOICES
sp.p: And give our lives , if need be , for this thing .

lg.l: So long ! So long !

sp.speaker: HARRY EGERTON
sp.p: Wherever men get free they 'll think of us .

sp.speaker: BUCK BENTLEY
sp.p: And there was something else . The General came while you were speaking .

sp.speaker: BUCK BENTLEY
sp.p: Something about some bugles you said get .

lg.l: Yes , I forgot . I meant to show you these
That a Committee brought this afternoon .
lg.stage: Takes a paper from his pocket
lg.l: Read them in the meeting , Harvey .
Some resolutions of the citizens ,
Who are glad we 've gone on peaceably to work .
And if at any time we need their help ——

lg.stage: Taking a bugle and holding it up to the crowd
lg.l: The citizens say blow these if we need help !
Because we 've gone on peaceably to work .
It 's work , you see , that wins , comrades .

sp.speaker: HARRY EGERTON
sp.p: I trust , though , that they 'll never need to blow .

sp.speaker: BUCK BENTLEY
sp.p: ‘ Twill set the land on fire if they do .

sp.speaker: A WORKMAN
sp.p: The workingmen throughout the State will hear .

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: They 'll blow in relay , pards , from sea to sea .

div.stage: Harry Egerton stands and watches the militiamen depart . As Bentley goes down the stairs he turns and looks at Harry Egerton , who lifts his hand to his head in a sort of military salute

lg.l: That 's what they say about us , Wes , you know
That when the thing we 've fought is taken away
We 'll fight among ourselves .
I ai n't a man ,
And never have been one , to set my views
Against the boys ’ views . If they 're satisfied
And think the new way 's better than the old ,
And if they 'll vote for it , Wes and his friends
Will have no grouch .
To get along together , as Sam says ,
That 's what we seek , my friend . The rest will come .

sp.speaker: WES DICEY
sp.p: It 's for the boys I took the stand I did .

div.stage: The workmen go back into the mill . Harry Egerton watches Dicey until he is lost among the men that pass out rear

lg.l: HARRY EGERTON .
lg.stage: Who has started to follow the men
lg.l: What is it , Harvey ?

sp.speaker: HARRY EGERTON
sp.p: We cannot be too patient with these men . It 's a free mill we 're trying to build , Harvey .

lg.l: ‘ Tai n't that I mean .
lg.stage: Takes the will from his pocket
lg.l: Why did you give me this ?

lg.stage: To Jim King , who lingers about beyond the railing
lg.l: We 'll be there .
If anything should happen to me , you know ,
My father would inherit everything .
And God meant the mine for other things .
And as administrators you and Sam
And Buck I knew would carry on the work .

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: But why just now ? Come on and tell me , partner . There 's something up . You ai n't been like yourself . There 's something on your heart . What is it , partner ? It ai n't the faction ?

lg.l: About the mine —
That lie they told is eating in your heart .
Have I done anything that you know , Harvey ,
That could have wronged the men or any of them ?

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: You wronged them ? What you mean ?

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: Why they 'd die for you , partner . What you mean ?

lg.l: Come here to-night when we can be alone .
There are some things I want to tell you , Harvey ,
That you and Sam and Buck must carry out .

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: Looks at him a long while , then lays his hands upon his shouldersWe 're on the eve of seeing things come true And there ai n't nothing that can stop it , partner .

sp.speaker: HARRY EGERTON
sp.p: I do n't know what I 'd do without you , Harvey .

div.stage: They go back through the gate in the railing and out through the great door , left , whence the crowd has passed . Rome Masters comes furtively up the stairs and looks about . He then comes past the sash to the door , forward left , and begins to pull off the strip that is nailed across it . He has just loosened it when Jim King appears upon the stairs and gives a low whistle . Rome Masters quickly joins him and together they hurry back through the mill and out the great door , left . A moment later the First Guard comes up the stairs , followed by Ralph Ardsley and Bishop Hardbrooke
The Guard goes back through the mill

sp.speaker: BISHOP HARDBROOKE
sp.p: I do n't like this . The atmosphere 's too charged with victory .

sp.speaker: RALPH ARDSLEY
sp.p: I do n't believe they even know it 's cold .Looks aboutIt 's wonderful the way he 's handled things . It 's that , I think , as much as anything That 's won the confidence of the citizens . I was just sure they 'd have a riot here .He gets up on one of the stools before the desk and takes from his overcoat pocket a newspaper which he spreads out before himI 've thought about it , Bishop ; do n't you think That that injunction Egerton got out Against the mine , considering everything , The public feeling — if he has good grounds For claiming that his own men found the mine — Aside from the reflection on his son — A tactical mistake , do n't you think so ?

div.stage: He reads the paper . The Bishop stands listening to the indistinct noises that come from the crowd outside

sp.speaker: RALPH ARDSLEY
sp.p: And yet you can n't blame Jergens very much . Something has got to happen pretty soon . Amalgamated 's off again , I see .

lg.l: He 's the rough
That kept the men from going back that day .
Drew his revolver . Big man here now . You see
He 'd been out on the mountains with a cast ,
One of the men the Company had out .
So it 's quite possible , as Jergens claims ,
That Anderson found the mine . For gold these days —
To get possession of a mine like that —
Men have been killed for less .
That ,
That 's what I can n't get down me , his collusion ——
It 's probably Anderson haranguing them .
I do n't myself believe that Harry 'd do it .
There 's certainly enthusiasm there .

sp.speaker: BISHOP HARDBROOKE
sp.p: What 's it all mean ? What 's underneath it all ?

lg.l: We 're neither of us , Bishop , what we were .
We 've lost our power . Something 's happening
That we do n't understand .
And done by men
That live right here and walk the streets and talk ,
Buy vegetables and pass the time of day .
I tell you , Bishop Hardbrooke , you can n't tell .
As though they had the Ark of the Covenant .
If any one had said to me last week
That that despondent crowd of shabby men ,
After six weeks of battle against odds ,
And beaten into silence , starved and cold ,
Had in them the capacity for this —
Who was it said we 're always in a flux ,
That nothing 's fixed ? We do n't know anything .
It 's like a case of type ; to-day it spells
Egerton and to-morrow M-o-b .
To think of Donald Egerton at bay !
Egad !
These shouts once rose about the Church ,
But somehow we do n't hear them any more .
Do n't think for a moment , Bishop , that you 're alone .
We never had the tumult and the shout
That you had in old days , but it 's all the same .
The ‘ Power of the Press ’ ! It makes me laugh .
If I could find a little farm somewhere ,
I 'd sell my stock to Egerton and get out
And let the world go hang . I 'm tired of it .
Yes , there 's a ring about it you do n't hear
Even in Conventions .

div.stage: The Guard enters the mill , back left , and comes through the gate in the railing
The Guard goes out down the stairs

lg.l: What 's your opinion of the trouble , Bishop ?
To think of Donald Egerton at bay !
We 've had the matter up in Conference
Several times .
But I somehow feel
We do n't get hold of it . The lower classes —
They 're going off . I do n't believe it 's Christ .
You say they 're leaving you ; and General Chadbourne —
Two thirds , I think you said , of his command .

div.stage: Cheers outside . The two men remain silent

lg.l: And Egerton —
They certainly have left him . I thought last night
As I sat looking up toward that new home —
They 'll never light it up again that way ,
The way it was that day . Did you ever see
Anything to equal that reception hall ?
What 's in the boy that these men follow him ,
And all his life so quiet , almost timid ?

sp.speaker: RALPH ARDSLEY
sp.p: ‘ What go ye out into the wilderness for to see ? ’

sp.speaker: BISHOP HARDBROOKE
sp.p: Yes , if his cause were better .

lg.l: But this audacious , this deliberate
Stealing — though I hate to use the word —
This seizing of the mill ——
Here he comes now .
lg.stage: He gets down from the stool
lg.l: You do the talking , Bishop , the heavy part .

div.stage: Harry Egerton enters

lg.l: You do n't seem
To mind the cold or anything down here .
I should think so . Yes
It 's wonderful the way you 've plunged right in
To business .
Harry ,
We 've come to see if something can n't be done
To end this controversy and bring peace ,
An honorable peace to all concerned .
A permanent state of strife is far from pleasant .
There 's nothing sadder in the life of man
Than to see towns disrupted , classes arrayed
Against each other , to say nothing , Harry ,
Of this far dearer tie that 's straining here ,
That pains us all far more than we can tell .
We 've often had these troubles in the Church ,
Mostly in the past , of course , men differing
Upon some point of doctrine or government .
And my experience is that at the bottom
There 's something that at first was overlooked ,
Then , in the strife that followed , overwhelmed .
There 's common ground , there must be in these things .
Look at the world ; we pass along the street .
We do n't confront each other and block the way .
Each yields a bit and so we all pass on .
And in relationships it must be the same .
We 're one , my brother .
And when we 're not , when interests seem to clash ,
It 's just as sure as Death or anything
Some law of God is being tampered with .
And so we thought we 'd come ——
For , as you know , in town the feeling 's growing
That there 's a sword impending over us
Which the least breath will bring down on our heads .
And not in the town alone , but the whole State —
They seem to have their eyes upon us here .
You 've seen the papers how the strikes are spreading .
The mills at Upton and the plant at Sawyer ,
And down the State there 's Smith and Balding Brothers ,
Heacox and Knight , twelve hundred men gone out ,
Demanding unconditionally the mills .

sp.speaker: BISHOP HARDBROOKE
sp.p: Think of it , Harry , think of what this means !

sp.speaker: RALPH ARDSLEY
sp.p: Not satisfied with wages any more .

div.stage: Walks rear and listens

sp.speaker: BISHOP HARDBROOKE
sp.p: He does n't listen to what I say .

lg.l: Not that you are to blame for it , we do n't say that .
But probably without your knowing it
A fire or something 's going out of you
That 's kindling this industrial upheaval ;
For it 's your name they 've made the war-cry , Harry .
He even smiled when you spoke of the mills
Closing .

sp.speaker: RALPH ARDSLEY
sp.p: I do n't think he meant it so . His heart 's out there , though , that 's as plain as day .

lg.l: Harry , if these shouts mean a final step ,
A closing up of things which if once closed
Will render of no use any labor of ours ,
I beg of you to call this meeting off ,
At least until we see what we can do .
Postpone it , Harry , say till Monday morning .
You know yourself how dangerous it is
To wake men 's hopes to a wild dream of power .
They 're never afterwards content with less
Than that wild something that could never be .
Yes , brother , let the Lord 's day with its peace
Breathe on this quarrel . Why do you say too late ?
Because it 's up there , Bishop , it 's up there
Above mere bread .

sp.speaker: RALPH ARDSLEY
sp.p: What does he mean by that ?

sp.speaker: BISHOP HARDBROOKE
sp.p: I trust , my brother , that it is up there .

sp.speaker: RALPH ARDSLEY
sp.p: We do n't just see what it is you are trying to do .

sp.speaker: HARRY EGERTON
sp.p: The statement I gave out last Saturday ——

lg.l: And since then
Reports have come out that there 's a move on foot
To organize — I know not what to call it ——

sp.speaker: RALPH ARDSLEY
sp.p: Your purpose then is to retain the mill ?

sp.speaker: HARRY EGERTON
sp.p: I do n't know . We 'll do what 's fair . We 've had to think first of supplying bread . That 's left but little time for other things .

sp.speaker: BISHOP HARDBROOKE
sp.p: But if the Company should n't choose to sell ?

sp.speaker: RALPH ARDSLEY
sp.p: You mean you 'll still hold on ?

sp.speaker: HARRY EGERTON
sp.p: That will be my advice , yes .

div.stage: Harry Egerton walks rear and listens

sp.speaker: RALPH ARDSLEY
sp.p: Does n't that beat the world !

sp.speaker: BISHOP HARDBROOKE
sp.p: It 's his association with these roughs .

sp.speaker: RALPH ARDSLEY
sp.p: And they 'll never dare lay hands upon them , Bishop . I tell you the Commonwealth 's afraid to move .

sp.speaker: BISHOP HARDBROOKE
sp.p: Has God no place in business , my young brother ?

lg.l: Yes , Bishop Hardbrooke , and it 's very strange
You 've never thought of that until to-day .

sp.speaker: BISHOP HARDBROOKE
sp.p: A hidden meaning couched in that , I think .

lg.l: This is the first time you 've been in this mill
Or near these workingmen in all these years .
And now you come to plead my father 's cause .
Then why not weeks ago
When there was strife ? You heard the cry of the poor
For six weeks , Bishop , and you never came .
Why wait until the starving time is past ?
I 've rather arduous duties , my young brother .
Besides my Church work there are Boards and Boards
And meetings of this Charity and that
That you in business know but little of .
My interest in the poor is not unknown .
