sp.speaker: HARRY EGERTON
sp.p: You 've been in father 's confidence for years .

sp.speaker: BISHOP HARDBROOKE
sp.p: I 'm proud to say I have .

lg.l: There 's seldom passed
A Sunday that he 's not been in his pew .
And one that any son might emulate
With profit , I should think .
It 's very strange
My father does n't know some things are wrong .

sp.speaker: BISHOP HARDBROOKE
sp.p: You mean he does n't see things as you do .

lg.l: Yes , all my life I 've wondered when I 've seen
Check after check go out with father 's name
To help along some Mission over sea
Or roof some rising Charity at home ,
I 've often wondered that he 's never seen
Those little shacks upon the hill out there
Nor heard the cry of widows from these saws .
I would suggest , my brother , that we leave
The deeper things of God for quiet times
And turn our minds to something nearer home .
I know of nothing nearer home than this ,
The cry of men for justice at our doors .
Suppose we get the Company to agree
To let bygones be bygones with the men ,
And to restore conditions as they were ——

sp.speaker: RALPH ARDSLEY
sp.p: In other words to meet the men 's demands .

lg.l: And put the guards they ask about the saws .
That would remove the causes , would it not ,
Of the misunderstanding ?
Would there be any valid reason then
Why Peace should not return and all be friends
As formerly ?

sp.speaker: HARRY EGERTON
sp.p: For weeks they waited for it .

div.stage: Listens back

sp.speaker: BISHOP HARDBROOKE
sp.p: What 's time to do with right and wrong , my brother ?

lg.l: But men in misery often have a vision
Beyond the eye of prosperous days to see .

sp.speaker: BISHOP HARDBROOKE
sp.p: If it was fair last week , then why not now ?

div.stage: Walks back

lg.l: On what foundations , Harry ? All about
I see the wreck and ruin of our land ;
Her altars down , her sacred institutions ——
Harry , I beg of you to stop and think
What it has cost , this Law that you defy
And cast before the swine of riotous feet .
I appeal to you , my brother ——

sp.speaker: BISHOP HARDBROOKE
sp.p: In the name of everything that you hold dear ——

sp.speaker: HARRY EGERTON
sp.p: There 's nothing you could say that could persuade me ——

sp.speaker: BISHOP HARDBROOKE
sp.p: Think of your country plunged in civil war !

sp.speaker: HARRY EGERTON
sp.p: To stay even with a word what 's rising there .

lg.l: Think of your mother , think of how she feels
Sitting ——

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: Hurrying inWell , President of Free Mill Number One And many more hereafter !Goes quickly left and , seizing the rope , pulls the flag up on the poleUp the mast , My beauty ! Now you 'll hear ‘ em raise the roof .

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: Moved to make it unanimous . No opposition .

div.stage: Tremendous cheering outside

lg.stage: Comes right and takes Harry Egerton 's two hands in his
lg.l: Well , boy ?

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: You 've dreamed it and it 's a fact now , partner .

div.stage: Prolonged cheering

sp.speaker: RALPH ARDSLEY
sp.p: Let 's leave ‘ em and let ‘ em stew in their own juice .

div.stage: A volley of shots

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: There goes the boys ’ salute !Seizes Harry Egerton by the shoulders and lifts him off his feetUp with you , up into the skies with you ! We 've lived to see a day will live forever . And you come right on out and make your speech .

div.stage: Hurries back through the mill

lg.l: I suppose
There 's no use in our talking any more .

div.stage: The Bishop and Ardsley go out down the stairs . Harry Egerton starts back toward the gate

lg.stage: Suddenly appears just beyond the railing
lg.l: There was a call just now ‘ fore you came in .
I think it was your mother .

div.stage: Harry Egerton turns back to the desk and takes up the telephone . Jim King vanishes through the great door , left

lg.l: Forty-nine
Grand View , please . Yes .
Mother ? I knew your voice .
You called me up , one of the men said . No ?
Or some one else .
Yes , mother , very well .
You 're going to the city ?
That was it .
I thought perhaps you had called me up to ask .
Four or five hundred pounds .
Mixed , I should say .
And such toys as you think children would like .
O you know more about such things than I .

div.stage: A pause

lg.l: Mother , while I think of it , has father
Had any trouble with Jergens ?
Ah , I 'm glad .
I overheard him talking with some men
The other night , and thought from what he said
It might be father they were talking of .

div.stage: A pause . The door , forward left , opens slowly and Rome Masters comes stealthily in with a bar of iron in his hand , and moves toward Harry Egerton , whose back is to him

lg.l: I 'm very glad . You might ask father though .
I 'll have some news for you when you return .
Here in the mill . And I 'll be Santa Claus .
That will be beautiful .
And , mother ——

div.stage: Masters strikes him

He sinks to the floor . Masters , iron in hand , flees down the stairs . The cheering outside continues . Then , as the noise subsides , there is heard a steady buzzing of the telephone as though some one were trying to get connection

div.head: ACT V

sp.speaker: CHRISTMAS EVE
sp.p: Scene : Inside the large room of a newly built board cabin up at the mine . Centre , rear , the open mouth of the tunnel , with the wall resting upon the rocks above . Left , in this same wall , near the corner , a door opening outside . Right , near the other corner , about four feet up from the floor , a small oblong window through which one sees the snow lying thick upon the mountains , and beyond the snow the dark of the sky with the winter stars shining brightly . In the right wall , well back , a door opens into a bedroom . Centre , in the opposite wall , a second door opens into a sort of woodshed . Left , a little way to the rear from the centre of the room , a heavy iron stove with chairs standing about . A woodbox is over near the wall , left . Forward right , a table with a bugle lying upon two or three sheets of loose paper , and , farther over , a heap of ore samples in which , with the light of the near-by lamp falling upon them , the gold is plainly visible . Harvey Anderson , his hat pulled low over his eyes , sits with his back to the bedroom , staring at the stove . The only motion discernible is an occasional pressing of the lip when he bites his moustache . Later , Mrs. Egerton , careworn and evidently in deep distress , enters from the bedroom and starts to say something to Harvey Anderson , but decides not to . Instead she goes to the window and stands looking out as though she were anxiously waiting for some one . Time : Christmas Eve .

lg.l: It 's after midnight , for the lights are out
Down in the town . It must be after one .
lg.stage: Speaks back as though into the bedroom
lg.l: You think the guard would let him come right through ?

sp.speaker: MRS. EGERTON
sp.p: I did n't mean to wake you , Harvey .

div.stage: Turns again to the window

lg.l: The snow 's so deep upon the mountains , mother .
And Sam and Chris — I know they 'd hurry on —
They ai n't come either .
It 's stopped snowing now .

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: It 's getting colder . How 's he seem to be ?

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: There 's very little change . What time is it ?

lg.l: Going on half past three .

div.stage: They look at one another
Anderson goes to the woodbox and looks in

lg.l: If I only knew ! If I only knew he 'd come !

lg.stage: As Anderson goes into the woodshed
lg.l: He may have telegraphed for specialists .

div.stage: She glances toward Mrs. Egerton , then goes quietly to the door , rear left , and looks out

lg.l: I wish that there was something that I could do .

sp.speaker: MRS. EGERTON
sp.p: You made it plain that he must come at once ?

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Yes , Mrs. Egerton . I told the truth . Some think it 's better to deceive . I do n't . And I find that people thank you in the end .

sp.speaker: MRS. EGERTON
sp.p: And they 've been gone since nine .

lg.l: Lie down a while ,
Wo n't you ? I wish you would .
It 's Mr. Bentley with the guard , I think .

div.stage: Mrs. Egerton leaves the window and walks about the room

lg.l: The stars are so low down , so beautiful ;
And the world so full of joy . Is n't it strange ?
To-day we 're here and to-morrow somewheres else .

div.stage: She stops by the bedroom door and stands looking in

lg.l: And he loves you so .
It 's always ‘ mother ’ when he speaks at all ;
You and the mill .
And then you 'll always know
There 's never been a man in Foreston
Been loved as he has been .

sp.speaker: MRS. EGERTON
sp.p: But he 's so young ! And his work — He 'd just begun . So little chance !

lg.l: I 've nursed so many cases of old men ,
And men in prosperous circumstances , too ,
Who 've had no friends at all , just relatives .

div.stage: Mrs. Egerton walks about

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: And friends are so much closer , do n't you think ?

lg.l: Has he never , never mentioned Donald 's name
In his delirium ?
But then you know
Those first weeks at the Hospital were a blank ,
Or almost so . And then when he came to
After the operation ——

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: I being a stranger , just a nurse , you know . In delirium of course it 's different . But then I 'd left the case .

div.stage: Harvey Anderson enters with an armful of wood

lg.l: I was surprised
When I got word from Mr. Anderson
That you had let him — It 's so far up here .

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: They always do . But they do n't always know what 's best for them .

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: But he was getting on so well .

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: There was no fever till four days ago .

lg.l: When I got here he was quite rational .
And talked about the mine here and the mill .
And figured out the timber that we 'd need
For next year 's run . I do n't know what it was .

div.stage: Quietly replenishes the fire

lg.l: He has n't moved .

lg.stage: Who has come to the table , picks up one of the sheets of paper
lg.l: And he was planning homes here for the men
Upon the valley land , with flowers and trees .

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Was n't it strange that he should hear the bells ?

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: I had n't heard them till he spoke .

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: He seemed to know that it is Christmas Eve .

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: It 's all right , mother , it 's all right .

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Wo n't you ? We 'll call you when he comes .

lg.l: Here comes a light .
If there 's anything , Harvey , anything I can do
To help the work along , you 'll come to me .
Promise me that . And you must keep right on .

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: Yes , mother . We talked of that .

div.stage: Mrs. Egerton kisses him and goes into the bedroom
She goes to the window

sp.speaker: BUCK BENTLEY
sp.p: You did n't think he 'd come .

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: He 's been six weeks , almost . But that 's all right . Is the Doctor with him ?

lg.l: Yes .
I 'll tell the boys .

div.stage: He goes out . Anderson stands staring at the door

lg.l: I 'm so , so glad .
These weeks and weeks —— It 's been so hard to bear .
You see when Death comes , Mr. Anderson —
It ought to be a lesson to us all .
You 'll stay , of course .
He 's felt so hard ,
So bitter toward you .

div.stage: Buck Bentley enters quickly . Looks from Harvey to the Nurse
Sam Williams and Chris Knudson come in with a lantern

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: See anything of Egerton coming up ?

div.stage: The men show surprise

sp.speaker: SAM WILLIAMS
sp.p: Is he as bad as that ?

lg.l: He has n't been himself .
Then come back .

div.stage: Anderson turns and shakes his head at the Nurse , who goes into the bedroom , closing the door after her

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: He spoke of both of you .

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: I thought you 'd like to be here .

div.stage: They sit silent about the stove
They are silent
Sam Williams nods
They are silent

lg.l: There 's a report
That Masters will turn State 's evidence .

sp.speaker: CHRIS KNUDSON
sp.p: The citizens are pressing on the case .

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: They 'll find the trail leads where we said .

sp.speaker: SAM WILLIAMS
sp.p: His throwing down the silver do n't help though .

div.stage: They are silent

lg.l: You see about those young pines , Chris . With spring
We 'll begin setting out as partner wished ,
And start all over with the land all green .

div.stage: They are silent

sp.speaker: CHRIS KNUDSON
sp.p: The boys will be so sorry .

lg.l: I do n't mind ,
Now that it can n't be , telling you of a plan ——

div.stage: There is a slight noise in the bedroom . Anderson turns and listens ; but everything becomes quiet again

lg.l: Of a surprise he had for Christmas day ,
For all of us and the families of the men .

lg.stage: Appears at the door and calls quickly
lg.l: Harvey !

div.stage: Anderson starts for the bedroom . Suddenly Harry Egerton appears struggling with his mother and the Nurse . His head is bandaged and his face is covered with a six weeks ’ beard

sp.speaker: HARRY EGERTON
sp.p: No , no ! See there ! see there ! see there ! They 're here already !

div.stage: A shadowy line of workmen with their wives and children in their Sunday clothes comes in left

lg.l: In the dry-kiln , Sam !
And fetch the other barrel , Harvey .
A Merry Christmas , friends , to all of you !
I 'm glad you 've come !
It 's all right , it 's all right !
Candy , candy , candy , children !

div.stage: The children crowd about him

sp.speaker: HARRY EGERTON
sp.p: Let them come ! let them come ! There ! there ! there !

lg.l: Is n't it wonderful !

sp.speaker: HARRY EGERTON
sp.p: And here 's a little doll and here 's a sled ! I brought them down over the chimney tops !

div.stage: Laughs . A little boy remains after the other children have gone back to their parents
The little boy returns to the others

sp.speaker: HARRY EGERTON
sp.p: Advancing and shaking hands with the men and women , who file by him and pass out rearNext year , my friends , if everything goes well , We 'll have some homes to hang up on the tree With big yards where the little ones can play . But this is children 's day .

div.stage: Last in the line comes a figure in the garb of a workman , but with the tender , bearded face of the Christ

lg.l: Have you been hurt ?

div.stage: The figure holds out both hands to him

lg.stage: At first wildly , but with growing calmness
lg.l: Harvey ! Buck ! Mother !

div.stage: The figure looks back one moment , then vanishes . Harry Egerton is seen falling into the arms of Harvey Anderson , who carries him into the bedroom . His mother and the Nurse follow . Sam Williams and Chris Knudson stand staring across at the door

lg.stage: Coming in and closing the bedroom door after him
lg.l: Partner 's gone .
Egerton 's come .

div.stage: Donald Egerton enters , followed by the Doctor and two strange men , apparently surgeons , one of them carrying an instrument case . Egerton glances about and instinctively locates the bedroom , and at once goes toward it

lg.stage: As Egerton opens the bedroom door
lg.l: Donald ! Donald !

div.stage: The Doctor follows Egerton into the bedroom

lg.stage: Looking toward the door that the Doctor has shut
lg.l: Peace and good will on earth .

div.stage: They stand silent about the stove . Anderson picks up two chairs , which he takes over to the two strangers , who are standing by the table

sp.speaker: CHRIS KNUDSON
sp.p: There 's things about us here that we do n't see .

lg.l: I 'm sorry — for his sake .

sp.speaker: SAM WILLIAMS
sp.p: You 'll not desert us , comrade , now he 's gone .

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: ‘ For all time ; shall we say it ? ’

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: ‘ And give our lives , if need be ? ’

div.stage: Takes up the lantern

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: He has n't left the Cause , Sam .

lg.l: That 's true ;
He has n't left the Cause .
Here just last week ,
Sitting about the table , planning things ,
‘ The Cause will be here , Harvey , when we 're gone ,
A beautiful river flowing through the land . ’

sp.speaker: CHRIS KNUDSON
sp.p: There was the noblest boy this land 's brought forth .

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: And we must make it wider , Sam .

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: Till the whole land is free . That 's our work now .

sp.speaker: SAM WILLIAMS
sp.p: Yes , we must keep right on .

lg.l: That was his wish ,
That we should keep right on ; and his mother 's , too .
Tell the boys that .
There ought to be
A public funeral so the men could march .
That 's him .

div.stage: The two workmen go out

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: Stop by the cabins and tell Buck . Good-night .

div.stage: He shuts the door and walks about , stopping occasionally by the stove , absorbed in thought
They take up pieces of the ore

lg.stage: To Anderson , who is walking about
lg.l: How much does this assay ?

lg.stage: Enters with the Doctor and speaks with him aside
lg.l: Drive down a mile or so and wait for me .

div.stage: Mrs. Egerton and the Nurse come in . Both are dressed for travelling

lg.stage: Walks toward the outer door , then suddenly turns
lg.l: O Donald , Donald , this is Christmas Eve !
Think of this night in years gone by !
Mary !

div.stage: She embraces him and goes out with the Nurse

lg.l: And you 'll attend to everything ?

div.stage: The Doctor goes out . Egerton shuts the door and stands for a moment apparently waiting till those who have just left get farther from the cabin . He then starts pacing to and fro as though he were undecided what to do . As he walks left toward Harvey Anderson his brow darkens . But as he turns right and draws near the bedroom the hard lines of his face relax . It is clear that a terrible struggle is going on within him

lg.l: You here alone ?

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: Yes , Mr. Egerton . But that do n't matter if there 's anything ——

div.stage: Egerton stands for a moment , then resumes his walk

sp.speaker: HARVEY ANDERSON
sp.p: Is there something I can do ?

sp.speaker: EGERTON
sp.p: Stopping midway between the bedroom and Anderson , to the strangersWhat do you say ?

sp.speaker: FIRST STRANGER
sp.p: We 'll do the best we can .

div.stage: The Second Stranger removes his overcoat . The First lifts the instrument case upon the table and begins to open it . Egerton walks toward the bedroom

lg.l: I do n't believe —
I do n't believe , though , Mr. Egerton ,
It 's any use .

sp.speaker: FIRST STRANGER
sp.p: Suddenly covering Anderson with pistols which he has taken from the caseKeep those hands where they are . Bolt that door , Ned .

div.stage: The Second Detective bolts the outside door . He then comes to the table and takes from the case two pairs of handcuffs , a long black mackintosh , and a black cap

lg.stage: Feels about Anderson 's hips and sides
lg.l: Slip on this coat .

lg.stage: To Egerton , while the detective puts the coat on him
lg.l: Well , partner , I 've seen men where Hell was loud
Shoot from behind dead bodies but , by God ,
I 've never seen them shoot from such as him .

div.stage: Nodding toward the bedroom

sp.speaker: FIRST DETECTIVE
sp.p: We keep the road to the left .

sp.speaker: EGERTON
sp.p: Over the mountains . You 'll probably have some trouble .

lg.l: I 'll have the Express wait for you at Lucasville .
You ought to reach there ——
It 's now five o'clock ——
By ten or eleven .

div.stage: The Second Detective hands to Egerton his son 's will , which , in buttoning the coat up about Anderson , he has found in the latter 's pocket

lg.l: Um !

sp.speaker: SECOND DETECTIVE
sp.p: The guard will be off duty ?

lg.l: I think so ,
But we 've no time to lose .

div.stage: The Second Detective handcuffs himself to Anderson on the left side . The First Detective puts the cap on Anderson so that with the high collar of the coat turned up , only his eyes are visible under the poke
The First Detective then handcuffs himself to Anderson on the right side

sp.speaker: EGERTON
sp.p: You wire me when you reach the Capitol .

lg.l: Now not a word from you , you understand .

div.stage: He puts the pistol in his side overcoat pocket and keeps his hand on it

lg.l: Yes , you 'd better leave
Before the land wakes up .

div.stage: The detectives , with Anderson between them , go out

lg.l: We 'll see , my man —
lg.stage: Puts the key on the outside of the door
lg.l: How you 'll shake down the pillars of this land .

div.stage: He goes out and locks the door after him . A few moments pass . Suddenly at some distance outside a shot is heard . Again a few moments pass . Then , with a crash , the door is broken in and Buck Bentley , with the will in his hand , pulls himself hurriedly through the hole . He staggers to the table and seizes the bugle and blows a loud blast , then reels and , trying to steady himself , falls dead upon the floor , taking the table down with him . There is a clattering of the ore samples and a breaking of glass , and the lamp goes out , leaving the room in darkness . A half mile or so away , in the direction of Foreston , a bugle is heard , then , farther away , another , and fainter , another , and still another . And out through the window in the starlight of the Christmas morning soldiers with rifles in their hands are seen running rear left through the snow
